prompt: Plans to convert a disused underground bunker into a music centre have been backed by Wiltshire councillors.
HWT: Harnham bunker, officially known as Salisbury Urban District Control Centre, has been empty for years. Youth group The Sound Emporium plans to convert it into its new base and said, being underground with thick walls, it's the ideal place for a music venue. But concerns were raised about potential noise, vibration and litter by some of those living nearby. Council officers advised the impact would not be "unduly harmful" and there were also letters of support. The plans for a change of use were approved at a meeting of Wiltshire Council's southern area planning committee on Thursday. Ross Sanderson, of the Sound Emporium, told the BBC the venue was "unique" and "inspiring". "What better place to have a music venue than underground, with the natural soundproofing of the earth plus between 5ft-10ft thick concrete walls?" Salisbury City Council owns the bunker, once an old military telephone exchange which became the council's control centre in 1963. The bunker still has some of its old typewriters and fittings - and an escape hatch.
MGT:
Wiltshire councillors have given their backing to ambitious plans that would transform a disused underground bunker into a state-of-the-art music centre, marking a significant step forward for the innovative cultural project.

The former military installation, which has remained largely unused for decades, is set to be converted into a modern facility designed to support local musicians and provide community access to professional-grade recording and performance spaces. The unique venue would offer acoustically optimized rooms, rehearsal facilities, and educational programs for aspiring artists of all ages.

Local councillors praised the project's potential to breathe new life into the historic structure while addressing the region's need for accessible music facilities. The underground location is expected to provide exceptional sound isolation, making it ideal for both recording and live performances without disturbing neighboring areas.

Project organizers emphasized that the conversion would preserve the bunker's historical significance while creating opportunities for emerging talent in the region. The facility aims to serve as both a creative hub and an educational resource, offering workshops, masterclasses, and collaborative spaces for musicians across various genres.

Planning permission is expected to move forward pending final environmental assessments and funding confirmation. If approved, construction could begin within the next eighteen months, with the music centre potentially opening to the public by late 2026.

prompt: Gary Locke has left his post as Cowdenbeath manager to become an ambassador for Hearts, with Billy Brown named the Blue Brazil's new boss.
HWT: Locke was in charge at Central Park for the second half of last term and guided the club to a play-off win over East Kilbride that kept them in League Two. Brown, who has worked alongside Locke in the past, helped out at Cowden towards the end of last season. The club say their aim remains to secure promotion next season. Cowdenbeath chairman Donald Findlay told the club website: "I am sorry to see Gary leave. However, in his time at Central Park we have become friends and I always made it plain to him that I would not stand in his way if the opportunity came along to join a bigger club. "I am well aware of his affection for Hearts, who have acted with absolute propriety in this matter, as I would expect. I will always be grateful for what he and Billy Brown did for the club at the end of the season and I have every confidence that Billy will carry on the good work." Locke, who becomes the Tynecastle outfit's principal ambassador, is taking up the post in the "club's commercial department" and will also "work alongside director of football Craig Levein in assisting to monitor the numerous loan players the club have across the country". The 42-year-old, who played for Hearts from 1992-2001, also managed the Edinburgh side in the 2013-14 season. Hearts chairwoman Ann Budge told the club's website: "We are thrilled that Gary is back working with us in such an important role."
MGT:
Gary Locke has departed his role as Cowdenbeath manager to take up a new position as ambassador for Hearts, with the League Two club moving quickly to appoint Billy Brown as his replacement.

Locke, who had been in charge of the Blue Brazil since his appointment, leaves Central Park to return to Tynecastle in an ambassadorial capacity with the Edinburgh club where he previously served as manager. The 48-year-old's tenure at Cowdenbeath saw him work to stabilize the club's position in Scotland's fourth tier while developing young talent and implementing his footballing philosophy.

Hearts moved swiftly to secure Locke's services in what represents a significant coup for the Gorgie outfit. The ambassador role will see him utilize his extensive knowledge of Scottish football and his connections throughout the game to benefit the club's various initiatives and community programs.

Billy Brown steps into the vacant managerial position at Cowdenbeath with immediate effect. The experienced coach brings a wealth of knowledge to the role, having worked extensively throughout Scottish football in various capacities. Brown faces the challenge of maintaining the momentum built during Locke's time while putting his own stamp on the team's approach.

Cowdenbeath chairman expressed confidence in Brown's ability to lead the club forward, citing his coaching credentials and understanding of lower-league football as key factors in his appointment. The transition comes at a crucial time in the season, with the club looking to build on recent performances and push for a stronger league position.

The move represents an intriguing development for both clubs, with Hearts gaining an experienced football mind in their ambassadorial ranks while Cowdenbeath welcome a new voice to guide their on-field ambitions. Brown is expected to take his first training session this week as he begins preparations for upcoming fixtures.

prompt: Cuba returned to the United States an inert Hellfire missile that had been wrongly shipped to Havana in June 2014.
HWT: The missile, which did not contain explosives, had been shipped to Spain for a Nato training exercise, the Wall Street Journal said. It was then taken to Germany and eventually to Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris for onward delivery to Florida. It was instead loaded on to an Air France flight to Havana. The incident could have led to a serious loss of military technology, officials told the Wall Street Journal. The whole affair has been embarrassing for the Americans, who have had to ask the Cubans if they could have their highly sensitive missile back, says the BBC's Will Grant in Havana. The missile arrived on a flight from Paris "by mistake or mishandling in the country of origin," said a Cuban Foreign Ministry statement. "Cuba acted with seriousness and transparency and co-operated to find a satisfactory solution to this issue," it added. The AGM 114 Hellfire is a laser-guided missile that can be deployed from an attack helicopter or an unmanned drone. US officials were worried that Cuba could share the advanced technology inside the missile with countries such as North Korea, China or Russia, sources close to the investigation told the Wall Street Journal. The US and Cuba, old Cold War enemies, restored diplomatic relations in July last year after more than 50 years. The two countries have been working to rebuild their economic and trade ties. An announcement is expected on Tuesday about the reinstatement of scores of commercial flights between US cities and Havana.
MGT:
Cuba has returned an inert Hellfire missile to the United States that was mistakenly shipped to Havana in June 2014, marking an unusual diplomatic exchange between the two nations amid their historic rapprochement.

The missile, manufactured by Lockheed Martin, was supposed to be sent from a NATO training exercise in Spain back to the United States but was instead diverted to the Cuban capital through what officials described as a shipping error. The weapon contained no explosive warhead and posed no immediate security threat.

Cuban authorities discovered the misrouted missile and informed U.S. officials of its presence on the island. The return comes as both countries work to normalize relations after decades of Cold War-era hostility, with the Obama administration having recently restored diplomatic ties and eased some economic sanctions.

The Hellfire missile is typically used by military drones and helicopters for precision strikes. While this particular unit was inert and used for training purposes, its advanced guidance technology raised concerns about potential intelligence value if it had fallen into the wrong hands.

U.S. officials expressed gratitude for Cuba's cooperation in returning the weapon, viewing it as a positive gesture that demonstrates growing trust between the former adversaries. The incident highlighted vulnerabilities in military shipping procedures and prompted reviews of logistics protocols for sensitive equipment.

The missile's return was facilitated through diplomatic channels, with both governments treating the matter as a routine administrative issue rather than a security crisis. This measured response reflects the broader effort by both nations to move beyond past conflicts and establish a more constructive relationship.

The successful resolution of this unusual situation represents another small step in the gradual thawing of U.S.-Cuba relations after more than five decades of estrangement.

prompt: The sequel to 2009 hit Avatar has been delayed a year and will not be released until 2017, James Cameron has revealed.
HWT: The Oscar-winning director of Aliens and Titanic said he is working on three new Avatar films at the same time. The first film was supposed to be out in December 2016, but Cameron said writing the stories had become "very involved". "There's a layer of complexity in getting the story to work as a saga across three films," he explained. Cameron said the goal was to have the scripts for the three movies completed by the end of this month so that filming can begin. "We're writing three simultaneously and we've done that so that everything tracks throughout the three films," he told the Associated Press. "We're not just going to do one and then make up another one and another one after that. "And parallel with that, we're doing all the design. So we've designed all the creatures and the environments." Cameron said he thought it was important that each film linked forward to the next one in a satisfying way, but also came to a resolution that did not leave the audience hanging. The three films will be shot in New Zealand, where some of the original film was also made. Avatar is the highest-grossing film in history, with box office takings of almost $2.8 billion (Â£1.8 billion). Set in the 22nd Century on a distant planet inhabited by a humanoid race, the sci-fi epic went on to win three Oscars. Cameron, 60, was speaking at an event in Wellington on Wednesday to promote the New Zealand film industry.
MGT:
James Cameron has announced that the highly anticipated sequel to his 2009 blockbuster "Avatar" will be delayed by a full year, with the release now pushed back to 2017.

The filmmaker revealed the news during a press event in New Zealand, where pre-production work on the sequel has been underway. The original film, which revolutionized 3D technology and remains the highest-grossing movie of all time with nearly $2.8 billion in worldwide box office, was initially expected to spawn a follow-up much sooner.

"Making Avatar was a complex process, and the sequels are even more complex," Cameron explained. "The design process is very detailed and time-consuming. We're writing three films simultaneously, and we've had to develop our new software and pipeline at the same time."

Cameron had previously announced ambitious plans for not just one sequel but three follow-up films to be shot simultaneously. This expanded scope appears to be partly responsible for the delay.

20th Century Fox, the studio behind the franchise, declined to comment specifically on the postponement but released a statement expressing continued confidence in Cameron's vision.

Industry analysts suggest the delay may actually benefit the franchise in the long run by allowing more time to refine the groundbreaking visual effects that made the original such a phenomenon.

The original "Avatar" transported audiences to the lush alien world of Pandora and told the story of a paraplegic marine who finds himself torn between following orders and protecting the alien world he feels is his true home.

Cameron has previously hinted that the sequels will explore Pandora's oceans and other moons in the same star system, while continuing the story of characters Jake Sully and Neytiri.

The filmmaker remains confident that the wait will be worthwhile: "When you see what we're creating, I think it will be well worth the delay."

prompt: A charity whose office was destroyed when a bus ploughed into it has a new home after a fortnight of staff working on laptops and mobile devices.
HWT: Thirteen people were hurt when the single-decker hit the building used by Guide Dogs UK in the centre of Peterborough on Christmas Eve. The charity has moved into an office in the Orton Southgate area of the city. Helen Sismore, community engagement manager, said: "We should be back in our repaired office by April." The bus went through the bay windows on the front of the charity's regional office on Broadway. Passengers had a variety of minor injuries but no-one was injured in the office where three people were in back rooms. Ms Sismore said: "We heard and felt the crash and it was horrific and the timing on Christmas Eve didn't help. "We've been working using laptops wherever we can find wi-fi, such as our homes, cafes and libraries. "No clients have suffered because we've been in telephone contact using our mobiles and we've had a lot of support from our volunteers and the local community." She said the repair of the rented Broadway offices was being covered by the landlord's insurance and they were renting the temporary office on Cully Court at the market rate.
MGT:
A charity has finally secured new premises after spending two weeks operating from laptops and mobile devices following a devastating bus crash that destroyed their office building.

The organization's headquarters was completely demolished when a bus careered off the road and ploughed directly into the structure, leaving staff without a physical workspace and forcing them to continue their vital community work remotely.

For the past fortnight, dedicated employees have maintained essential services by working from home using personal laptops and mobile phones, ensuring that vulnerable clients continued to receive support despite the challenging circumstances. The charity's management praised staff members for their resilience and commitment during this difficult period.

Local authorities and the community rallied around the organization, offering temporary solutions and assistance in finding suitable alternative accommodation. Several businesses in the area volunteered space, while donors contributed funds to help cover relocation costs.

The charity has now moved into a new office space that will allow them to resume full operations and welcome clients back for face-to-face appointments. The building provides adequate room for staff and meeting areas for the various support programs they run.

Officials confirmed that the bus incident remains under investigation, while the charity focuses on rebuilding and continuing their important work serving the local community.

prompt: A man who defrauded a 98-year-old woman he befriended of £170,000 has been jailed for five years and one month.
HWT: Russell Joy, 45, of Shapwick, Dorset, set up direct debits, withdrew money and cashed bonds on behalf of Mary Brady, from Broadstone. Bournemouth Crown Court heard Joy won the trust of the pensioner, who died earlier this month, when she hired him as her gardener in 2008. He was entrusted to withdraw money for her daily living expenses. In December 2014 he made the first of 107 withdrawals without her knowledge, totalling £32,100. The following November Ms Brady cashed five bonds in the sum of £230,000 and wrote Joy a cheque for £100,000. In March 2016, he received a further £20,000 cheque. He also withdrew money to buy a Land Rover car and set up a direct debit to pay his vehicle insurance. The offences came to light when the pensioner's relatives checked her finances while she was in hospital. In a statement, Ms Brady's family said they were "desperately sad" about the "ugly end" to her life. Det Insp Andy Dilworth said: "Russell Joy is nothing more than a callous fraudster. He befriended his victim over a period of many years and quickly earned her trust." He said Joy ,who pleaded guilty at a previous hearing to six counts of fraud by abuse of position, would be subject to action under the Proceeds of Crime Act.
MGT:
A man who callously exploited the trust of a vulnerable 98-year-old woman, defrauding her of £170,000, has been sentenced to five years and one month in prison.

The defendant befriended the elderly victim before systematically stealing the substantial sum from her over an extended period. The court heard how he gained her confidence through what appeared to be genuine friendship, only to abuse that relationship for financial gain.

The victim, who trusted the man implicitly, was left devastated both financially and emotionally by his betrayal. The fraud involved sophisticated manipulation tactics designed to exploit her vulnerability and advanced age.

Prosecutors outlined how the defendant carefully orchestrated his scheme, gradually gaining access to the woman's finances while maintaining the facade of friendship. The substantial sum stolen represented a significant portion of the victim's life savings, accumulated over decades of careful financial management.

During sentencing, the judge condemned the defendant's actions as particularly heinous given the victim's age and vulnerability. The court emphasized that crimes targeting elderly members of society would be met with severe punishment.

The case highlights the ongoing problem of financial abuse against elderly individuals, with authorities urging families and communities to remain vigilant for signs of exploitation. Social services and financial institutions have implemented additional safeguards to protect vulnerable adults from such predatory behavior.

The defendant showed little remorse throughout the proceedings, further aggravating his sentence. The victim's family expressed relief at the outcome while acknowledging the lasting impact of his betrayal on their loved one's wellbeing and financial security.

prompt: Protesting opposition MPs in Kosovo have released tear gas in parliament for the sixth time in just over two months, disrupting a vote on the government's 2016 budget.
HWT: Outside, opposition supporters threw stones and smashed windows before they were dispersed by riot police. Protesters have been trying to disrupt parliament over an EU-brokered deal to improve relations with Serbia. Kosovo unilaterally declared its independence from Serbia in 2008. The opposition first released tear gas in parliament on 8 October, causing two MPs to faint. US Secretary of State John Kerry, on a visit to the capital, Pristina, earlier this month, called for an end to violent scenes in parliament, saying it was "not the place for tear gas and... not the place for intimidation". However, opposition MPs released gas canisters again in the parliamentary chamber on Monday, forcing a suspension of proceedings. A large group of plainclothes police officers donned gas masks as the chamber was cleared. One of the MPs who released the gas, Glauk Konjufca, said it was "a collective action by the opposition". "Others have done this too, and we will continue to do this in the future. Our breaching of the law is nothing compared to the damage that is being done by these agreements." The opposition is particularly opposed to a deal to give more autonomy to Kosovo's ethnic Serb minority, which they say could increase Serbia's influence. The vote on next year's €1.67bn (£1.1bn) budget resumed in a side room, with only MPs from the governing coalition present and was approved, Reuters news agency reported. The US ambassador to Kosovo, Greg Delawie, condemned the disorder, saying it was "very disappointing" that Mr Kerry's calls had gone unheeded.
MGT:
Opposition lawmakers in Kosovo's parliament deployed tear gas canisters during a legislative session on Thursday, marking the sixth such incident in just over two months as political tensions continue to escalate in the Balkan nation. The disruptive protest forced the suspension of a crucial vote on the government's proposed 2016 budget.

The tear gas release sent lawmakers, government officials, and parliamentary staff scrambling from the chamber as the acrid smoke filled the room. Security personnel quickly evacuated the building while emergency crews worked to clear the air. The session was immediately suspended, with no indication of when proceedings might resume.

Opposition parties have been staging increasingly dramatic protests against the government's policies, particularly objecting to agreements reached with neighboring Serbia and Montenegro. The repeated use of tear gas has become a signature tactic of the opposition, which argues that the ruling coalition has betrayed Kosovo's national interests through various diplomatic concessions.

Prime Minister Isa Mustafa's government has condemned the disruptive tactics, calling them undemocratic and harmful to Kosovo's international reputation. Government supporters argue that the opposition is preventing legitimate governance and blocking important legislation that would benefit Kosovo's citizens.

The stalled budget vote represents a significant obstacle for the government, which needs parliamentary approval to implement its spending plans for the coming year. The proposed budget includes provisions for infrastructure development, social programs, and economic initiatives designed to address Kosovo's high unemployment rate and economic challenges.

International observers have expressed concern about the ongoing political crisis, warning that the instability could harm Kosovo's European integration aspirations. The European Union has called for dialogue between political parties to resolve their differences through democratic means rather than disruptive protests.

Kosovo declared independence from Serbia in 2008 and has been working to establish stable democratic institutions while pursuing international recognition and European Union membership.

prompt: Manufacturing sales from Northern Ireland were worth £13.3bn last year, the highest value on record.
HWT: External sales were up by 3.2% over the year, a rise of £415m. The biggest market for those goods is Great Britain which accounts for £8.1bn - just under half the total value. The Republic of Ireland is the next single biggest market at £1.3bn, followed by the rest of the EU at £1.2bn. Sales to all other parts of the world were £2.6bn. The figures suggest that Northern Ireland manufacturing may be benefiting from the recoveries in the wider British and Irish economies. Sales to GB were up by 6.2% while sales to the Republic of Ireland were up by 5.3%. However sales to other EU countries fell by 13%. The figures are produced by the  Northern Ireland Statistics and Research Agency (NISRA). Richard Ramsey Ulster Bank chief economist in Northern Ireland said one of the key themes from the figures is the growing importance of the GB market for NI's manufacturing firms. He said: "Whilst there have been huge efforts by policymakers to encourage local firms to export to markets outside of the UK, Great Britain has been the fastest growing market for NI's manufacturers following the downturn. "Since 2007/08, NI's manufacturing sales to GB have increased by almost one quarter (+23%) or £1.5bn. "In 2012/13 NI's manufacturers sold six times more goods, in value terms, to the GB market than they did to the Republic of Ireland. "Back in 2007/08,  local manufacturers sold just over three times more goods to the GB market than they exported to the Republic of Ireland."
MGT:
Manufacturing sales from Northern Ireland reached a record-breaking £13.3 billion last year, marking the highest value ever recorded for the region's industrial sector. The milestone figure represents a significant achievement for Northern Ireland's economy and underscores the growing strength of its manufacturing base.

The record-breaking performance reflects the resilience and adaptability of Northern Ireland's manufacturing companies, which have successfully navigated challenging global economic conditions while continuing to expand their operations and market reach. Industries across the region contributed to this historic total, demonstrating the diverse nature of Northern Ireland's manufacturing landscape.

Local manufacturing businesses have benefited from strategic investments in technology, infrastructure, and workforce development over recent years. These improvements have enhanced productivity levels and enabled companies to compete more effectively in both domestic and international markets. The sector's success has also been supported by favorable business conditions and government initiatives designed to promote industrial growth.

The achievement comes at a time when manufacturing sectors worldwide have faced numerous pressures, including supply chain disruptions, rising material costs, and shifting consumer demands. Northern Ireland's ability to achieve record sales despite these challenges highlights the sector's fundamental strength and the effectiveness of local business strategies.

Manufacturing remains a cornerstone of Northern Ireland's economy, providing thousands of jobs across the region and contributing substantially to overall economic output. The sector encompasses a wide range of industries, from traditional manufacturing to advanced technology production, each playing a vital role in the region's economic ecosystem.

Industry leaders have expressed optimism about future prospects, citing ongoing investments in innovation and technology as key drivers for continued growth. The record sales figure provides a solid foundation for further expansion and reinforces Northern Ireland's position as a competitive manufacturing destination within the broader UK and European markets.

prompt: A racehorse has survived a two-hour swim, covering 11km, after being scared during a training run on a beach in Brisbane, Australia.
HWT: Rebel Rover was being trained in chest-high water at Sandgate beach when he unseated his rider and headed deeper. The five-year-old gelding was picked up by the Brisbane Water Police and a marine rescue unit. "He was in about four metres of water and he was swimming quite freely," said Volunteer Marine Rescue's Glen Philip. Rebel Rover, with a track record of misdemeanours, has only recently made a comeback after being banned for misbehaving in the stalls. Trainer Brad Smith told ABC News that horses could swim, but did not normally do so very much. "Any other horse, 20 minutes would probably see them out, but this horse - he must have a pretty amazing lung capacity," he said. "The vet looked at him yesterday and again this morning and he's pretty well amazed with how he's coped with it all. Brisbane's Courier Mail reports he still had enough energy to head butt one of his support team, knocking them unconscious and putting them in hospital. Rebel Rover has won three of his 12 races.
MGT:
A racehorse made an extraordinary 11-kilometer journey through Moreton Bay waters after bolting during a beach training session in Brisbane, surviving a grueling two-hour swim that has amazed veterinarians and horse racing experts.

The thoroughbred was participating in routine beach training when something spooked the animal, causing it to flee into the waters off the Queensland coast. Instead of turning back to shore, the panicked horse continued swimming further into the bay.

Emergency services were quickly alerted as the horse disappeared from view. Marine rescue crews launched an immediate search operation, scanning the expansive waters for any sign of the animal. After two hours of swimming, the exhausted horse was finally located and successfully guided back to shallow water.

Veterinarians who examined the horse afterward expressed amazement at its survival, noting that few horses could endure such an extended period in open water. The animal showed signs of exhaustion but no serious injuries, making a remarkable recovery considering the ordeal.

Beach training is common practice for racehorses, as the soft sand provides excellent conditioning while being gentler on their legs. However, this incident has prompted trainers to review safety protocols when conducting seaside sessions.

The horse is expected to make a full recovery and return to training within weeks.

prompt: Trainer Kevin Ryan has been suspended from running horses after a case of equine herpes was found at his yard.
HWT: Only one case has been discovered in Ryan's string but the yard near Thirsk has been placed under quarantine by the British Horseracing Authority (BHA). The nearby stables of trainers Bryan Smart and Michael Herrington have also been quarantined as a precaution. The BHA said they are working with Ryan and staff to ensure the correct disease control measures are in place. "The risk of the virus being transmitted in a controlled race-day environment is relatively small," said David Sykes, the BHA's director of equine health and welfare. "[But] it is in theory possible that horses from the yard in question may have been infectious some time before the disease was diagnosed. "For this reason we have taken measures to alert trainers, as well as racecourses and veterinary surgeons, to be vigilant to the clinical signs." The equine herpes virus can cause respiratory disease and abort foetuses, while a less common neurological form of the virus can cause co-ordination problems and paralysis, and is potentially fatal. The National Stud breeding site in Newmarket was closed last year following the discovery of the neurological herpes virus infection. Ryan won the French Derby and Irish Champion Stakes in 2014 with The Grey Gatsby and is a four-time winner of the Ayr Gold Cup, including the 2016 edition with Brando.
MGT:
Trainer Kevin Ryan has been temporarily barred from entering horses in races following the discovery of equine herpes at his training facility. The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) confirmed the suspension after veterinary tests identified at least one case of the highly contagious virus at Ryan's North Yorkshire yard.

Equine herpes virus (EHV) can cause respiratory problems, abortion in pregnant mares, and in severe cases, neurological issues that can be fatal. The virus spreads rapidly through direct contact between horses or via contaminated equipment and clothing.

A BHA spokesperson stated, "Following confirmation of EHV-1 at Kevin Ryan's yard, we have implemented standard biosecurity protocols to prevent further spread of the disease. Mr. Ryan has cooperated fully with the investigation."

The suspension is expected to remain in place until veterinary officials are satisfied the outbreak has been contained. All horses at the yard are being monitored for symptoms, with strict quarantine measures now in effect.

Ryan, who has trained numerous Group 1 winners throughout his career, will be unable to send runners to upcoming fixtures, potentially impacting his stable's participation in several important autumn meetings.

Racing officials have advised trainers with horses that may have come into contact with Ryan's string in recent weeks to monitor their animals closely and report any suspicious symptoms immediately.

The BHA emphasized that this measure is precautionary and designed to protect the wider horse population from what could become a more significant outbreak if not properly contained.

prompt: The Environment Agency is reviewing the flood risk around the English coastline from high waves.
HWT: It says some of its existing maps may underestimate the risks to coastal communities. It is updating its National Flood Risk Assessment which informs members of the public and local authorities about the likelihood of flooding. The Environment Agency grades coastal areas at risk of flooding from very low to high. Environment Agency flood risks: High: Greater than one in 30 chance in any given year Medium: One in 30 to one in 200 chance in any given year Low: One in 200 to one in 1000 chance in any given year Very low: Less than one in 1,000 chance in any given year Last winter massive storms hit the South West coast with waves up to 15m (50ft) high, destroying part of the main railway line out of the region at Dawlish. Marcus Salmon, planning liaison technical specialist with the agency, said: "The storms have definitely reflected areas where our maps are not as representative as they can be. "That is something that we are working to address as quickly as possible. "Last winter's storms showed the susceptibility of our coastal communities and infrastructure to flooding and erosion. "The challenges presented by flooding and coastal erosion are expected to become more acute as a result of climate change, due to a combination of sea level rise, increased storminess and increased wave heights. "So as to better understand the risks we are updating the National Flood Risk Assessment to take account of wave, wind and storm surge which are underrepresented in our current mapping."
MGT:
The Environment Agency has launched a comprehensive review of flood risks facing England's coastline as concerns mount over the increasing threat posed by high waves and storm surges.

The assessment will examine vulnerable coastal areas across the country, analyzing wave height data, tidal patterns, and the potential impact on communities, infrastructure, and natural habitats. Officials say the review comes amid growing evidence that coastal flooding events are becoming more frequent and severe.

"We are seeing changes in wave patterns and storm intensity that require us to reassess our understanding of coastal flood risk," said a spokesperson for the Environment Agency. "This review will help us better protect communities and ensure our flood defenses are fit for purpose."

The study will particularly focus on areas where high waves combined with spring tides and storm conditions could overwhelm existing sea defenses. Coastal regions in the southwest, east coast, and areas around major estuaries are expected to receive priority attention.

Climate scientists have noted that rising sea levels, coupled with more intense weather systems, are creating conditions where traditionally safe coastal areas may face unprecedented flooding risks. The review will incorporate the latest climate projections and wave modeling technology to assess future threats.

Local authorities along the coast have welcomed the initiative, with many reporting increased incidents of wave overtopping and coastal erosion in recent years. The findings will inform future investment in coastal defenses and help guide planning decisions for new developments in at-risk areas.

The Environment Agency expects to complete the initial phase of the review within the next twelve months, with detailed recommendations for enhanced flood protection measures to follow. Communities identified as facing elevated risks will be prioritized for defense upgrades and emergency preparedness improvements.

The review represents one of the most comprehensive assessments of England's coastal flood vulnerability undertaken in recent years.

prompt: A young Syrian man has gone on trial in Germany, accused of being deployed by so-called Islamic State to scope out potential targets in Berlin for attack.
HWT: Identified under German privacy laws as Shaas al-M, he claimed asylum in August 2015 and is now 20 years old. Federal prosecutors say before that he fought with the Islamist militants for two years in his home country. He is being tried by a special security court in Berlin, but reports suggest he refused to testify. He has been in custody since his arrest on 22 March. Shaas al-M's trial comes two weeks after Anis Amri ploughed a truck into a Christmas market in Berlin, killing 12 people. IS later released a video showing him pledging allegiance to its leader Abu-Bakr al-Baghdadi. A year of terror in Germany Berlin attack: Islamic State claims responsibility How attacks are forcing Germany to examine civil freedoms Dressed in a blue pullover and a black cap, he hid his face behind a folder as he took his seat in the courtroom, reported AFP news agency. Officers armed with machine guns were stationed outside the court. Shaas al-M faces charges of being a member of a foreign terrorist organisation, which carries up to 10 years in jail, and violating laws governing military weapons. In a previous statement (in German), the court detailed allegations of Shaas al-M's involvement in IS operations in Syria, including participating in the siege of the airport at Deir al-Zour, handling a Kalashnikov gun and helping supply fighters with food. Once he had arrived in Germany, he maintained intensive contact with IS superiors, it says, and began to undertake visits to Berlin where he explored landmarks including Alexanderplatz, the Brandenburg Gate and the Reichstag parliament building, reporting his findings back to his contacts. He is also accused of arranging for at least one person to travel to Syria to fight, and offering his services to assist would-be attackers travelling to Germany. The court has scheduled some 25 hearings to run until April.
MGT:
A 21-year-old Syrian man appeared before a German court this week, facing charges of reconnaissance activities for the Islamic State terrorist organization in Berlin. The defendant, whose identity has not been publicly disclosed due to German privacy laws, is accused of conducting surveillance operations to identify potential targets for future attacks in the German capital.

According to prosecutors, the man allegedly arrived in Germany as part of a broader IS strategy to infiltrate European countries and establish operational cells. Court documents suggest he was specifically tasked with gathering intelligence on crowded public spaces, transportation hubs, and government buildings throughout Berlin between 2023 and early 2024.

The case represents one of several recent prosecutions in Germany related to IS activities, highlighting ongoing security concerns about sleeper cells and radicalized individuals operating within European borders. German authorities have been particularly vigilant following previous terrorist incidents across Europe that were linked to Islamic State operatives.

During the opening proceedings, federal prosecutors outlined their evidence, which reportedly includes digital communications and surveillance footage placing the defendant at various sensitive locations throughout the city. One of the big advantages of li-fi is the fact that, unlike wi-fi,  it does not interfere with other radio signals, so could be utilised on aircraft and in other places where interference is an issue.
